participants of the control group played a version of the same game from which all violent content was removed, and were asked to perform a non-violent task (taking photographs of other characters).

StudyObjective: This study examined whether perceived friendship quality was related to better mental health and lower neural stress response in young people with CA.

StudyObjective: to investigate which brain regions are activated during food choices during HE compared to LE energy snacks in weight-concerned women

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants made 100 choices
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: in every trial, they viewed one of the study stimuli (3000 ms, choice period) and subsequently had to indicate with a button press (1500 ms, button press period) whether they wanted to eat a portion of the snack or not
Conditions: view one of the study stimuli
indicate with a button press whether they wanted to eat a portion of the snack or not
TaskMetrics: activation during HE (but not LE) snack choice in brain regions involved in conflict and self-control

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants decided to either pass or shoot the ball via button press
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Each situation was randomly shown twice and half of the feedbacks were preset to be positive (GOAL!) and the other half negative (MISS!), thus leading to 60 goals and 60 misses, respectively.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants guessed under which out of one to four randomly shown boxes a circle was hidden
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: in each of the 150 trials, a correct guess led to a positive monetary feedback (win) of 10 euro cents and a wrong guess to no monetary win (no win)

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: participants guessed under which out of one to four randomly shown boxes a circle was hidden
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: leading to winning probabilities ranging from 25% to 100%

StudyObjective: to investigate how the two factors (giver and type of gift) interactively determine the neural reward value of the gift

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Imagine you are having a birthday party at home. You have two male friends attending the party, one whom you prefer, and the other whom you are indifferent to. Each of them talks to you privately. Each tells you that he brought a birthday gift especially for you. Please judge the attractiveness of the gift that you receive on a 9-point scale, where 1 is the minimum and 9 is the maximum. You should evaluate only the gift, not the giver.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: event-related design

StudyObjective: to investigate how participants rate intentional and unintentional social norm violations with respect to inappropriateness and embarrassment, and we examined the brain activation patterns underlying the processing of these transgressions

StudyObjective: The Impact of Carotid Artery Stenting on Cerebral Perfusion, Functional Connectivity, and Cognition in Severe Asymptomatic Carotid Stenosis Patients
to study the neural mechanisms underlying the disambiguation of degraded spoken sentences in situations where the subject has previously been exposed to the intact versions of the sentences

Conditions: between the first and the second presentations of the distorted sentences
between the presentation of the intact sentences and the first presentation of the distorted sentences
between the presentation of the intact sentences and the second presentation of the distorted sentences
TaskMetrics: decreased activity for the second presentation of the distorted sentences in comparison to the first presentation bilaterally in the area extending from the posterior insular cortex to Heschl's gyrus (including Te1.2, Te1.0, and Te1.1) and planum temporale

Conditions: each subject was first presented with acoustically distorted sentences, then with the intact versions of the same set of sentences, and finally, with the distorted sentences again
TaskMetrics: the low intelligibility (mean: 41%) distorted sentences near to the perfect level (mean: 95%) after a single presentation of their intact counterparts

StudyObjective: Investigated the effects of music training on executive function using fMRI and several behavioral tasks, including the Color-Word Stroop task.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: During the Color-Word Stroop task, children with music training showed significantly greater bilateral activation in the pre-SMA/SMA, ACC, IFG, and insula in trials that required cognitive control compared to the control group, despite no differences in performance on behavioral measures of executive function.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Each block contained 12 trials, each presented for 1700ms with a 300ms interval between each trial (excluding the last trial in each block).
Conditions: children involved in ongoing music training
TaskMetrics: bilateral activation in the pre-SMA/SMA, ACC, IFG, and insula

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: During the Color-Word Stroop task, children with music training showed significantly greater bilateral activation in the pre-SMA/SMA, ACC, IFG, and insula in trials that required cognitive control compared to the control group, despite no differences in performance on behavioral measures of executive function.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each block contained 12 trials, each presented for 1700ms with a 300ms interval between each trial (excluding the last trial in each block).
Conditions: children involved in ongoing music training
TaskMetrics: bilateral activation in the pre-SMA/SMA, ACC, IFG, and insula

Here, we examine social information processing in children with ASD by probing brain circuit function and connectivity in response to human vocal sounds.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: presented in 10 separate runs, each lasting 4 min
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: one run consisted of 56 trials of mother’s voice, unfamiliar female voices, environmental sounds and catch trials

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: to determine if the participants could reliably discriminate their mother’s voice from unfamiliar female voices

StudyObjective: to investigate whether individual differences in recruitment of cognitive control regions during a difficult response inhibition task are associated with a failure to regulate neural responses to rewarding food cues in a subsequent task in a cohort of 27 female dieters

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants were required to actively inhibit reading a series of words that appeared on the screen over the course of seven minutes
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: adapted from Wagner and colleagues’ ( ) study that was modified to be amenable to neuroimaging analysis

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: involving food commercials that has previously been shown to reliably recruit the brain’s reward system
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: using independently defined,   a priori   regions/systems of interest
TaskMetrics: balance between regions associated with self-control and those associated with food-reward

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: following a milkshake preload, dieters will proceed to eat significantly more ice cream than those participants whose diets are not broken
TaskMetrics: total amount (grams) of ice cream consumed

StudyObjective: Understanding neural characteristics of casual MA users, particularly during risky decision-making, may help identify addiction-vulnerable phenotypes that could influence treatment response and thus represent novel therapeutic targets.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: decided to accept or refuse a series of mixed gambles
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: modified CUPS task
TaskMetrics: amount or number of wins or losses

StudyObjective: to investigate the relationship between food cue reactivity in the striatum measured one month after the onset of a weight loss program and weight changes obtained by the end of the six-month intervention

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: one before starting the six-month weight loss intervention (baseline, Session 1 ) and another at the end of the first month of the six-month weight loss intervention (Session 2 )
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: two separate fMRI imaging sessions

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: investigation of the patients' motivations, mapping the potential obstacles of weight loss, counseling about low calorie dieting, keeping a food diary, and encouragement for performing a voluntary intake restriction of approximately –500 kcal
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: low-calorie diet (1500 kcal/day)

StudyObjective: To understand the neural basis of N400 and how it is affected by SZ

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: in which words were either matched (APPLE←apple) by preceding pictures, or were unmatched (in-category; IC, APPLE←lemon) by semantically related (in-category; IC, APPLE←lemon) or unrelated (out of category; OC, APPLE←cow) pictures
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: half of the unmatched trials comprised picture-word pairs from a related semantic category (related co-hyponym, e.g., APPLE ←lemon) and the other half comprised picture-word pairs from unrelated semantic categories (unrelated, e.g., APPLE ←cow)

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: indicated the total number of people and lines on the book cover
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: hedonic and utilitarian goods were presented in a random order
Conditions: cued visually so participants knew in which block they were performing
TaskMetrics: perceptual levels: the total number of people and lines of the title in the book

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: choose the reasoning for the purchase of each book

StudyObjective: probe neural responsiveness to anticipated and received rewards in the context of bipolar disorder

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: scanned individuals with remitted bipolar I disorder (  n   = 24) and well-matched controls (  n   = 24; matched for age and gender)
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Each trial (8000×ms total) began with presentation of a visual cue (cue period; 2000×ms). Cue shapes indicated the valence (gain: circle, or loss: square) and horizontal lines across the cues indicated magnitude ($0.00: no lines, $0.20: one line, $1.00: two lines, or $5.00: three lines)

StudyObjective: to extend normative neurodevelopmental work into a high-risk population

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: where behavioral inhibition was assessed in the presence of appetitive and aversive socioaffective cues
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: during functional magnetic resonance imaging

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: where participants were instructed to inhibit a prepotent behavioral response while distracted by socioaffective cues

StudyObjective: to elucidate how the interplay between emotional cues and cognitive control differs between adolescents who show high or low levels of risk-taking behaviour

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: an emotional go/no-go paradigm
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: within a go/no-go paradigm participants are instructed to press a button as quickly as possible when shown a ‘go’ (i.e., target) stimulus and to inhibit their response by not pressing the button when shown a ‘no-go’ (i.e., non-target) stimulus
TaskMetrics: increased activation in the inferior frontal gyrus

StudyObjective: to investigate, for the first time, the functional development of the EBA, pSTS, FBA and amygdala in relation to the perception of emotional human body movements across childhood and adolescence

fMRITasks.TaskName: Passive viewing fMRI task using dynamic emotional bodies and non-human objects
fMRITasks.TaskDescription: adults showed increased activation in the body-selective areas compared with children
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: blocks of five clips (10¼s)

StudyObjective: investigated how the bilateral TPJs associated with ToM were involved in competitive decision making, in which correct inference of another’s inference about one’s own belief is essential.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: played the ‘asymmetric matching pennies game’ in the MRI scanner with three types of opponents: the human opponent (HUM) who played the game outside the scanner and the two artificial agents (FIX and LRN).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: the human opponent was described as a student of the same sex at the same university, FIX as a computer program that would always follow a fixed, economically rational strategy and LRN as a computer program that would constantly learn to predict the participant’s choices through interaction.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: played the ‘asymmetric matching pennies game’ in the MRI scanner with three types of opponents: the human opponent (HUM) who played the game outside the scanner and the two artificial agents (FIX and LRN).
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: the human opponent was described as a student of the same sex at the same university, FIX as a computer program that would always follow a fixed, economically rational strategy and LRN as a computer program that would constantly learn to predict the participant’s choices through interaction.

StudyObjective: to examine the relationship between sleep disruption–induced pain sensitivity and functional connectivity (FC) of cognitive networks contributing to pain modulation

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: designed to elicit intrinsic network connectivity without the risk of participants falling asleep

StudyObjective: examined brain activation related to parenting and ER in parent-adolescent dyads during concurrent fMRI scanning with a novel task – the Testing Emotional Attunement and Mutuality (TEAM) task.

fMRITasks.TaskName: Testing Emotional Attunement and Mutuality (TEAM) task
fMRITasks.TaskDescription: This task builds on past studies that have utilized error processing paradigms
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: event-related design and consists of 17 trials during which participants first see a pattern of colored arrows presented sequentially on the screen for 3 s, twice in a row (totaling 6 s). They are then given 4 s to reconstruct the sequence by pressing colored buttons on a response box
Conditions: error trials indicating the other dyad member made an error, resulting in a monetary loss for both participants
TaskMetrics: hemodynamic activation of the ventromedial prefrontal cortex

StudyObjective: to shed new light on the engagement of hippocampal-neocortical regions, and thus the role of memory-based mental simulation processes in pain empathy

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants had been randomly assigned to a placebo or control group and completed a pain empathy task, as well as an affective touch task (not discussed here)
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: using this approach, we analyzed a data set of 102 human participants who underwent functional MRI while painful and non-painful electrical stimulation was delivered to themselves or to a confederate

StudyObjective: Contextual modulation of social behaviour – a core part of healthy social function – is facilitated by the ability to map private states onto public actions in a flexible manner.
To present a Deep Learning framework for the prediction of chronological age from structural magnetic resonance imaging scans.

examine how conformity decisions are evaluated in the developing brain and unfold across social contexts, particularly when adolescents’ own opinions conflict with the opinions of their parents, peers, or both.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: On each trial, participants first viewed a behavior they previously rated (but were not reminded of their original ratings) (2 s). Following a jittered inter-stimulus interval (  M   = 2 s), participants were then shown their parents’ and peers’ ratings on
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Parents and peers (1) influenced adolescents’ attitudes toward unconstructive and constructive behaviors (i.e., type of behavior) and (2) endorsed attitudes that reflected either more positive or negative influence (i.e., type of influence).

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: On each trial, participants first viewed a behavior they previously rated (but were not reminded of their original ratings) (2 s). Following a jittered inter-stimulus interval (  M   = 2 s), participants were then shown their parents’ and peers’ ratings on
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Parents and peers (1) influenced adolescents’ attitudes toward unconstructive and constructive behaviors (i.e., type of behavior) and (2) endorsed attitudes that reflected either more positive or negative influence (i.e., type of influence).

StudyObjective: Brain structure correlates of expected social threat and reward
to apply functional measures of motor learning and plasticity

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: accurate, rapid tracing of randomize trail mazes
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: participants used an MRI compatible mouse to guide a cursor through a marked trail displayed on the monitor

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants move the mouse at random

StudyObjective: to extend this work by (1) employing a more refined assessment of food preference, craving, and consumption outcomes above and beyond BMI, (2) interrogating these patterns for both healthy and unhealthy foods, and (3) creating a more detailed model of behavior change over multiple time points.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were trained to decrease their desire to consume personally-desired (for task purposes these are referred to as “craved” foods) foods using cognitive reappraisal
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants viewed unhealthy craved foods ("Craved" condition), unhealthy not-craved foods ("Not Craved" condition), or healthy vegetables ("Neutral" condition).
TaskMetrics: craving for the food on a 5-point Likert scale

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Eating behavior was assessed via the Automated Self-Administered 24 h (ASA24) Dietary Assessment Tool
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: participants completed the ASA twice at each time point to obtain a more representative estimate of daily eating behavior

StudyObjective: Probing the relevance of the hippocampus for conflict-induced memory improvement

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: during functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI)
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: event-related design

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: to the previously seen faces
Conditions: during the fMRI task or the familiarization

StudyObjective: To introduce a new and time-efficient memory-encoding paradigm for functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: parallel mixed block/event-related fMRI designs measure transient and sustained information within a single, time-efficient paradigm that includes a large number of stimuli.

StudyObjective: examined sex differences in the neural responses to wins and losses and how individual reward and punishment sensitivity modulates these regional activities

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: press a button to collect reward ($1, 1¢, or nil)
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: reaction time window titrated across trials so participants achieved a success rate of approximately 67%
Conditions: receipt of dollar or cent reward
TaskMetrics: neural responses to wins and losses

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: exhibited greater arousal in response to “go” action

StudyObjective: Testing the degree with which healthcare providers take into account feedbacks about their pain assessment, and whether they weight in different extent the opinion of the patient from that of other physicians.
to test whether shared neural representations between first-hand pain and empathy for pain are pain-specific or extend to empathy for unpleasant affective touch as well

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: In this task, short-lasting (500 μs) and individually calibrated painful or nonpainful electrical stimulation was delivered to participants, or to another person (a confederate of the experimenters).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: trials were structured as follows: First, an arrow (2000 μs) indicated the target (self vs. other) of the upcoming stimulus.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Following the empathy for pain paradigm, we applied a touch paradigm ( ; ) including 15 pleasant, 15 unpleasant and 15 neutral stimuli in pseudo-randomized order.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In the first run (self-directed affective touch), the participant was stimulated to measure behavioral responses and brain activation related to the first-hand experience of affective touch.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Following the empathy for pain paradigm, we applied a touch paradigm ( ; ) including 15 pleasant, 15 unpleasant and 15 neutral stimuli in pseudo-randomized order.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: In the first run (self-directed affective touch), the participant was stimulated to measure behavioral responses and brain activation related to the first-hand experience of affective touch.

StudyObjective: to test whether young and older adults relied on different brain networks during successful spoken word recognition, and whether any age differences were related to the specific task

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: no response was required
listeners were 29 young adults (aged 19–30 years) and 32 older adults (aged 65–81 years) without self-reported hearing difficulty

StudyObjective: examined how MT impacts functional brain physiology in the regulation of reactive aggression

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: a 16-trial game in which participants could respond to provocation by choosing whether or not to retaliate in the next round
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: participants were randomly assigned to 2 weeks of MT (  n   = 11) or structurally equivalent active coping training (CT) that emphasizes cognitive control (  n   = 12)
Conditions: participants were randomly assigned to 2 weeks of MT (  n   = 11) or structurally equivalent active coping training (CT) that emphasizes cognitive control (  n   = 12)
TaskMetrics: enhanced ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) recruitment during punishment events
greater dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) activation when deciding how much to retaliate
desire to harm their opponent during completion of the TAP

StudyObjective: to identify the most reliable patterns of activation across several studies, regardless of the social category of distinction in any individual study
address the highly debated question of whether neural responses previously linked to affect sharing could result from the perception of salient affective displays
Altered Brain Structure in Chronic Visceral Pain: Specific Differences in Gray Matter Volume and Associations With Visceral Symptoms and Chronic Stress
to characterize developmental changes in brain activity related to the influence of a social stimulus on cognitive control and more specifically on inhibitory control

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants are asked to inhibit their reflexive eye movement to an abruptly appearing peripheral visual target and to reprogram a saccade in the opposite direction
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: using faces (social stimuli) or cars (nonsocial stimuli)

StudyObjective: highlighting patterns of brain activations and autonomic activity when confronted with high mental workload and the threat of auditory stressors

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: combines a classical n’back task with mental arithmetic
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: reproduces the mentally challenging conditions that operators face during degraded contexts

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: memorize and compare the results of arithmetic operations

StudyObjective: Growing in generosity? The effects of giving magnitude, target, and audience on the neural signature of giving in adolescence

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: adolescents divided either a small or large number of coins (giving magnitude manipulation) between themselves and either a friend or unfamiliar peer (target manipulation) in an audience or anonymous context (peer presence manipulation)
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: a modified version of the Dictator Game, which is an economic game traditionally used to study giving behavior
Conditions: target (i.e., giving to a friend or unfamiliar peer)
peer presence (i.e., anonymous versus audience giving)
TaskMetrics: giving more in the small size than large size condition
more to friends than to unfamiliar peers
more in the audience compared to anonymous condition

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: adolescents divided either a small or large number of coins (giving magnitude manipulation) between themselves and either a friend or unfamiliar peer (target manipulation) in an audience or anonymous context (peer presence manipulation)
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: a modified version of the Dictator Game, which is an economic game traditionally used to study giving behavior
Conditions: target (i.e., giving to a friend or unfamiliar peer)
peer presence (i.e., anonymous versus audience giving)
TaskMetrics: giving more in the small size than large size condition
more to friends than to unfamiliar peers
more in the audience compared to anonymous condition

StudyObjective: reveal the neural mechanisms of control processes underlying the retrieval of weak representations

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: retrieval of a strong representation
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: presenting a number (or a letter) during the 2Back trials after performing consecutive number (or letter) Classification trials

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: retrieval of a weak representation
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: presenting a number (or a letter) during the 2Back trials after performing sequential letter (or number) Classification trials

StudyObjective: To investigate whether increased hemodynamic activity in the PPA that is usually detected by contrasting blocks of pictures is also present under more natural conditions.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: offering ecologically more valid visual stimulation than a paradigm using blocks of pictures
offering an exclusively auditory stimulation

StudyObjective: Understanding the mechanisms underlying aging-related memory decline is likely to inform the development of compensatory strategies promoting independence in old age.

StudyObjective: Does losing money truly hurt? The shared neural bases of monetary loss and pain
evaluate correlation of sleep quality with visual attention and search, functional, and tracts’ properties of the DAN and VAN

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: visual search and attention
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: the subjects had to hold the mouse button until they have found a match, release it, and touch the target on a touch screen
TaskMetrics: mean RT change from 2 to 8 pattern trials

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: visual search and attention
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: the subjects had to hold the mouse button until they have found a match, release it, and touch the target on a touch screen

StudyObjective: to investigate the effects of music liking, familiarity, and self-selection on reward processing before and after intervention

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: The fMRI task consisted of 24 trials altogether.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In each trial, participants were first presented with a musical stimulus (lasting 20 s), then they were given the task of rating how familiar they found the music to be (familiarity rating lasted 2 s), and how much they liked the music (liking rating also lasted 2 s).
Conditions: other-selected (researcher-selected) music including well-known excerpts spanning multiple musical genres

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to pay attention to how the music affected their moods and emotions, while noting any memories, images, or associations with the music.

StudyObjective: to systematically investigate age-related differences in the effects of social closeness on trust behavior and the neural representation of reciprocity

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: played with a computer, a stranger, and a close friend who accompanied them to the experiment

StudyObjective: to investigate the neuronal relations of mechanical restriction

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: measured through the food cue reactivity task ( ) administered approximately 30 min after deflation/sham-deflation to allow for transportation to the research center and administration of a visual analog scale (VAS) on food intake motivation ( )
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: consisted of 44 food images [22 high energy-dense foods (HED), e.g., ice cream, cookies; 22 low energy-dense foods (LED), e.g., salad, fruit] matched on valence, arousal, image complexity, brightness, and hue, and 44 degraded images to serve as a visual baseline

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: measured through the food cue reactivity task ( ) administered approximately 30 min after deflation/sham-deflation to allow for transportation to the research center and administration of a visual analog scale (VAS) on food intake motivation ( )
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: consisted of 44 food images [22 high energy-dense foods (HED), e.g., ice cream, cookies; 22 low energy-dense foods (LED), e.g., salad, fruit] matched on valence, arousal, image complexity, brightness, and hue, and 44 degraded images to serve as a visual baseline

StudyObjective: re-examined the VAN and the DAN neuroanatomy by co-registering individual network maps in a common functional space

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: engaged in movement synchronization, using a novel dyadic interaction paradigm

StudyObjective: to investigate behavioral and neural associations in self-regulation across the two domains in human participants

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: reappraisal of positive and negative emotional stimuli
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: before each block of 20 trials, the condition ‘view’ or ‘reappraise’ was displayed for 1 s

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: dietary self-control task
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: participants were shown one food in the center of the screen on each trial and had to indicate within the 3-s response window whether they wanted to eat this food or nothing at the end of the study

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: dietary self-control task
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: participants were shown one food in the center of the screen on each trial and had to indicate within the 3-s response window whether they wanted to eat this food or nothing at the end of the study

StudyObjective: to examine how neighborhood disadvantage interacts with racial/ethnic background in shaping neural processing of social threats and rewards in US adolescents

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: measure neural responses to anticipating social rewards and threats
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed the Social Incentive Delay Task ( ) while undergoing fMRI to measure neural responses to anticipating social rewards and threats (see   )
